frameDefinitions: The Jury discuss the Case and its Charges in order to evaluate the  Possible_sentence of the accused.

The judge or other court officer (the Authority) informs the Accused of the Charges against him/her, i.e. the alleged actions and the relevant laws. '' 'The board has been accused by the federal court of making decisions based on narrow agendas and meddling where it shouldn't.'

At a court hearing, a Defendant is informed of the Charges against him or her, (usually) enters a plea, and a decision is made by a Judge as to the amount of bail, if any. '' 'Mortimer and Isabella were hurried off and arraigned before parliament in November.'

This frame covers a step in a criminal process in which a  Judge decides whether the Accused should be released on bail, and, if so, what the amount of the bail should be.  '' 'Thorsen, of Grimstad, Norway, was granted $100,000 bail until June 18.'
Authorities charge a Suspect, who is under suspicion of having committed a crime (the Charges), and take him/her into custody.'
In the Appeal stage of the criminal process the Convict or his or her Representative applies to a higher Court to reverse the Decision of the lower court on certain Grounds. '
frameExamples: The board has been <t>accused</t> by the federal court of making decisions based on narrow agendas and meddling where it shouldn't.
Mortimer and Isabella were hurried off and <t>arraigned</t> before parliament in November.
Thorsen, of Grimstad, Norway, was granted $100,000 <t>bail</t> until June 18.
The police <t>arrested</t> Harry on charges of manslaughter.
The defense plans to <t>appeal</t> the court's decision on the grounds that the judge violated Code 81.b .
listRoleDefinitions: The group that debates the case.
The legal label for the crime that the defendant is accused of.
The <fen>Case</fen> which a trial is convened to decide.
A sentence that the jury considers during deliberation.
When the deliberation takes place.
Where the deliberation takes place.
The judge or other authority of the court in which the accused person is arraigned.
The person being charged with an offense against the law.
The crime with which the Accused is charged
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Defendant</fen> is charged with a crime by a <fen>Judge</fen>.
The <fen>Judge</fen> is the head of the court where the arraignment occurs.
<fen>Charges</fen> is the crime with which the <fen>Defendant</fen> is charged.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the arraignment occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the arraignment occurs.
At the time of bail setting, the <fen>Accused</fen> is held without bail/bond, released on his/her own recognizance, or required to give the Court  a specific amount of money for bail.
The <fen>Judge</fen>, as head of  the Court, determines the <fen>Accused</fen>'s bail.
<fen>Status</fen> idenitifies the decision made with regard to bail.  The possible statuses are 'without bail/bond', 'on one's own recognizance', or a specific amount of money required for bail.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the bail setting occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the bail setting occurs.
<fen>Charges</fen> identifies a category within the legal system; it is the crime with which the <fen>Suspect</fen> is charged.
The <fen>Authorities</fen> charge the <fen>Suspect</fen> with commiting a crime, and take him/her into custody.
The <fen>Suspect</fen> is taken into custody, under suspicion of having committed a crime.
<fen>Offense</fen> identifies the ordinary language use of the reason for which a <fen>Suspect</fen> is arrested.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the arrest occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the arrest occurs.
The <fen>Convict</fen> is the individual convicted of the crime who may make an appeal on her or his behalf.
The <fen>Representative</fen> applies to a higher court on behalf of the <fen>Convict</fen>.
The <fen>Decision</fen> is the ruling handed down by the first court.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which a <fen>Convict</fen> or <fen>Representative</fen> appeals.
listRoleExamples: The jury deliberated for three hours <fex>last Tuesday.</fex>.
The jury deliberated for several hours <fex>in the Oakland courthouse</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> was arraigned on eight counts of treason.
Jan was arraigned on eight counts of treason <fex>before Duncan Smith</fex>.
Jan was arraigned <fex>on eight counts of treason</fex>.
Judge Duncan fixed <fex>the doctor's</fex> bail at one million dollars.
<fex>Judge Duncan</fex> fixed the doctor's bail at one million dollars.
Judge Duncan fixed the doctor's bail <fex>at one million dollars</fex>.
The police arrested Harry <fex>on charges of manslaughter</fex>.
<fex>The police</fex> arrested Harry on charges of manslaughter.
The police arrested <fex>Harry</fex> on charges of manslaughter.
The police arrested Harry <fex>on Wednesday afternoon</fex>.
The police arrested Harry <fex>in front of his house</fex>.
